statement.text: The Winslow pathway is a critical collateral route connecting the subclavian arteries to the femoral arteries via the internal mammary, superior and inferior epigastric, and external iliac arteries, providing essential alternative blood supply in chronic aortoiliac occlusive disease.
statement.formal: Winslow_Pathway: Subclavian → Internal_Mammary → Superior_Epigastric → Inferior_Epigastric → External_Iliac → Femoral

explanation.intuition: When the aorta becomes blocked, blood can't take the normal highway to the legs. The Winslow pathway is like a long detour through the chest wall - blood flows down through the internal mammary arteries in the chest, connects to the abdominal wall arteries, and eventually reaches the leg arteries from above.
explanation.key_insight: The Winslow pathway explains how patients with complete aortic occlusion can still walk. These collaterals hypertrophy over time in chronic occlusion. Surgeons must be aware of these dilated vessels during abdominal surgery - injury can cause significant bleeding and compromise lower extremity perfusion.
explanation.technical_details: The pathway flows: subclavian → internal thoracic (mammary) → superior epigastric → rectus sheath → inferior epigastric → external iliac → common femoral. Hypertrophies in chronic aortoiliac occlusion, coarctation, or after prior aortic surgery. These vessels can enlarge to 5-10mm diameter. Bilateral pathways typically develop. Associated with Leriche syndrome (aortic occlusion triad: claudication, impotence, diminished femoral pulses). Surgical implications: avoid injury during median sternotomy (dilated IMAs), abdominal surgery (epigastric vessels), or inguinal incisions. Embolization of IMAs before CABG may be problematic if Winslow pathway is the primary leg supply.

clinical_significance.leg_perfusion: May be sole supply to lower extremities in aortic occlusion

surgical_planning.laparotomy: Avoid epigastric vessel injury in midline
surgical_planning.inguinal: Enlarged inferior epigastric at risk during dissection

clinical_significance.CABG_considerations: Using IMA for CABG may compromise leg perfusion if Winslow is dominant

imaging.CTA: Visualizes hypertrophied pathway on coronal reconstructions

definition.@value: Collateral circulation connecting subclavian arteries to femoral arteries via internal mammary, superior epigastric, inferior epigastric, and external iliac arteries, providing lower extremity blood supply in aortoiliac occlusion.

learning_objectives: Trace the Winslow pathway from subclavian to femoral
Understand clinical scenarios where this pathway is critical
Recognize surgical implications of hypertrophied collaterals
clinical_pearls: Winslow pathway explains why patients with aortic occlusion can still walk
Internal mammary arteries may be SOLE supply to legs - beware during CABG planning
Dilated epigastric vessels at risk during abdominal surgery - significant bleeding if injured
Always assess collateral pathways before sternotomy in patients with known aortic disease
Pathway can be visualized on CTA with coronal reconstructions
